reasoning:
Well, I’ll be honest—I don’t invest in semiconductors. It’s outside my circle of competence. I understand soft drinks, insurance and railroads; I don’t pretend to grasp the twists and turns of chip design and AI acceleration. That alone rules it out.

As for a moat, Nvidia certainly earns hefty operating margins today, but its ROE has been negative in recent years and earnings are wildly inconsistent. A real moat shows up in durable profits year after year—See’s Candies and Coca-Cola delivered that, Nvidia has not.

Management hasn’t paid dividends or shown a pattern of disciplined capital allocation. When you’re running a business that loses money and changing capital requirements every quarter, you can’t judge stewardship by a couple of data points.

The balance sheet looks okay on debt, but negative owner earnings and unpredictable returns on capital are red flags. Buffett likes lumpy industries that promise steady free cash flow, not wild oscillations.

On valuation, the three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value and a negative margin of safety. You can’t pay a high multiple for uncertainty and expect to come out ahead.

I prefer wonderful businesses selling for fair prices over fair businesses at wonderful prices. Nvidia may be exciting, but it fails every step of my checklist. My capital would be better employed buying more Coca-Cola or adding to Apple, where I can sleep at night. So this one’s a no – I’m bearish.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of -5.1%; Conservative debt levels; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -179.7% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 38.9%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Inconsistent book value per share growth

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (3.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (1.5%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
